Interactions with water as a shared resource

column13: Stockland uses the Green Building Council of Australia's (GBCA) Green Star rating tools to support the design and delivery of water initiatives and set a platform for optimal performance. In Commercial Properties, all new Town Centre and Workplace developments and redevelopments (excluding small refurbishments and extensions) are required to achieve a minimum 5-star Green Star Buildings rating with a review of opportunities to reach 6 stars. In the Logistics developments, Stockland targets a minimum 4-star Green Star Buildings rating. Green Star sets minimum standards for water management, and certification assists its assets in meeting its water management targets. Stockland also collects data on water performance to understand opportunities for improvement.
column20: Green Star rating, Green Building Council of Australia, water management

column13: Stockland considers water-sensitive urban design (WSUD) in its developments. WSUD achieves sustainable water management in urban areas through integration with the urban design and considers all of the elements of the urban water cycle, including potable water, wastewater, rainwater, stormwater and groundwater. Stockland is required to meet minimum standards for WSUD across all projects, regardless of local requirements.
column20: Water Sensitive Urban Design, sustainable water management, water cycle

column13: Stockland installs water sub-metering systems to monitor water consumption in its Town Centre and Workplace assets. These systems have improved clarity on where water is being consumed and assisted Stockland's asset management teams in rectifying wastage more efficiently. Stockland also employs building optimisation services with data analytics partners and monitors day-to-day consumption about an ideal water consumption model.
column20: Water sub-metering system, water consumption, building optimisation service

column13: In its Communities portfolio, Stockland seeks to promote water-efficient landscaping to enhance water efficiency in the day-to-day lives of its communities. Water-efficient landscaping can include using rain sensors that can be controlled remotely to operate a drip irrigation system and specifying drought-resistant species for roadsides and parks or artificial turf instead of lawns. Other water-efficient landscaping initiatives include drought-resistant species in residents' sales covenants, low or no-irrigation landscaping and water tanks or basins to service irrigation needs.
column20: Water-efficient landscaping, water efficiency, rain sensor

column7: Stockland consumed 428,997 kL of non-potable water in 2023.

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column13: In FY23, Stockland completed a review of how it measures positive and negative impacts on biodiversity associated with its developments. Stockland found that there have been advances concerning the quantification of biodiversity outcomes since it first deployed its proprietary biodiversity calculator in 2015. Following this review, Stockland has started developing an updated calculator and approach to tracking biodiversity outcomes associated with its developments.
column20: Biodiversity calculator, biodiversity outcome, positive impact

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column13: For more than 10 years, Stockland has partnered with a renowned expert in frog habitat restoration to identify and create a habitat where frogs with distinctive habitat requirements can thrive. New research has revealed positive results from conservation efforts at Stockland Aura in Qld, with the Wallum Sedge Frog found to be used and breeding in specially created wetland habitats across the masterplanned community. Through collaborative efforts involving local communities, environmental groups and international experts, Stockland is actively rehabilitating 700 hectares of previously degraded pine plantation land into a fully functional ecosystem for frog species at Aura. Upon completion of the development, these areas will transform into permanent conservation lands.
column20: Frog habitat restoration, Wallum Sedge Frog, wetland habitat

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts

column13: Stockland created a business-led circularity workstream to support its work on circularity. A cross-business knowledge-sharing workshop brought together key team members across the business to share insights on projects piloting circularity principles. The workshop provided shared learnings across teams and a path forward in Stockland's Plan to maximise short-term wins and create opportunities for a more substantive shift towards circularity across the business.
column20: Circularity workstream, knowledge-sharing workshop, circularity principle

column13: Stockland's masterplanned community, The Gables, in NSW, has successfully embraced and integrated circular economy principles to construct the site's temporary food precinct. Through a partnership with Stockland's contractors and the application of adaptive reuse, the project has increased its use of reclaimed, salvaged, or reused materials. Repurposing of existing assets has been championed on site, with a shearing shed repurposed into a glass house function room and an old school bus repurposed into a food truck. The materials ecosystem has been tracked to strengthen Stockland's data, improve material transparency and increase its understanding of the materials' value for their recovery and reuse.
column20: The Gables, circular economy principle, temporary food precinct

column13: As part of its ongoing development at M_Park in NSW, Stockland recognised an opportunity to identify building items within the existing asset due for deconstruction suitable for reuse. The team engaged a third-party consultant to identify appropriate partners for the materials and create a material reuse catalogue for the site. All materials identified within the internal fit out of the existing asset and 40 per cent of building materials were deemed salvageable, including elements of the aluminium faÃÂ§ade, steel handrails, glass partitions and carpet tiles.
column20: Material reuse catalogue, steel handrail, glass partition

column13: Stockland incorporated new waste reporting criteria into its waste contracts and adopted requirements from the Better Business Partnership (BBP) Operational Waste Guidelines into its waste and recycling contract specifications, which will be a significant step towards providing more accurate data on waste recovery and disposal. This improved accuracy will allow Stockland to understand how waste is managed and develop appropriate strategies to increase diversions.
column20: Better Business Partnership, waste contract, Operational Waste Guidelines

column6: Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations

column13: Stockland's materials selection and usage are governed by its Materials Schedule, which guides projects and suppliers in selecting materials following its sustainability policy. The materials schedule provides a consistent approach to selection and use across the business. The schedule is intended to provide an overview of the key requirements for projects to encourage environmentally responsible actions and assist projects in selecting environmentally friendly materials.
column20: Materials Schedule, sustainability policy, environmentally-friendly material

column6: New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
column13: Stockland requires that contractors comply with all relevant environmental protection legislation, including contamination and waste dumping. Contractors must provide a strategy during the tender process to outline how to meet the minimum requirements. During construction, contractors submit documentation to Stockland to validate their adherence to these standards. Stockland's construction contracts in each business unit require the relevant building contractor to develop an Environmental Management Plan (EMP) so that construction activities reflect the vision and design requirements and respond appropriately to policy and regulation.
column20: Environmental protection legislation. Contamination, waste dumping
